author: By Jess Bidgood
title: The Democrats’ Answer to Hulk Hogan
description: Tim Walz will embody his party’s retort to the mega-masculinity of Trumpism on display last month.
content: For better or worse, the image burned most permanently into my brain after the Republican National Convention was that of Hulk Hogan, ripping off his shirt in a display of testosterone-fueled camp that has come to be an integral part of former President Donald Trump’s Make America Great Again movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: A Film Festival Founded in a War Zone, Still Going Strong
description: The Sarajevo Film Festival, now 30 years old, grew out of underground screenings during the siege of the city. Those roots still define the event’s character.
content: From 1992 to 1996, Serbian forces laid siege to the city of Sarajevo, relentlessly bombarding it and cutting off electricity, heat, running water and regular food supplies. Because of snipers perched on hillsides and constant shelling, going outside was a life-threatening act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Nick Corasaniti, Olivia Natt, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Eric Krupke, Patricia Willens, Lexie Diao, Michael Benoist, Dan Powell, Corey Schreppel, Rowan Niemisto, Diane Wong and Chris Wood
title: The Republican Plan to Challenge a Harris Victory
description: How a right-wing takeover of an obscure, unelected board in Georgia could swing the election.
content: At the Democratic National Convention, party officials are celebrating polls showing that Kamala Harris is now competitive with Donald Trump in every major swing state across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Our Election 2024 Student Conversation Forums
description: Starting Sept. 10, we’re inviting teenagers to reflect on their civic and political values, beliefs and identity and share their perspectives on current issues.
content: Teenagers have plenty to say about the state of the world. They often know more about what’s working — or not working — in their communities than adults do. They follow the news, even if they learn more from social media than from traditional sources. And they care deeply about the future and how to make it better.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: For China’s Road Trip Heroine, A Bold Step on a New Journey
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, August 22, 2024.
content: “Even though money is very important, freedom is more important.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: 30-Year Mortgage Rate Dips to 6.46%; Home Sales Rise
description: Home buyers this week saw the lowest average rate since early 2023, and existing-home sales rebounded in July. Analysts predict more relief ahead.
content: Mortgage rates dipped this week to a recent low, with analysts predicting a sharper drop in the coming months that could motivate potential home buyers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megha Rajagopalan
title: Sugar Industry Faces Pressure Over Coerced Hysterectomies and Labor Abuses
description: After an investigation that ran in The New York Times, the industry is edging toward change. But companies in western India are reluctant to abandon an abusive labor system.
content: The sugar industry is facing pressure to clean up its supply chains and improve oversight after revelations that women in India, the world’s second-largest sugar producer, work in debt bondage and are coerced into getting hysterectomies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Full Transcript of Tim Walz’s Speech at the Democratic Convention
description: The Minnesota governor compared the election to a football game, vowing that and he and Vice President Kamala Harris would fight “one yard at a time” and “leave it on the field.”
content: Wow. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Wow. Thank you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Yermak
title: A Combat Medic’s Quest to Change Tributes to Fallen Soldiers
description: Iryna Tsybukh, who was killed on the front line in Ukraine, wanted to humanize the way Kyiv commemorated the war dead. She also left notes for her own funeral.
content: Her funeral would be “awesome,” the young Ukrainian combat medic said, if it went as she had planned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Can the Democratic Party Reclaim Freedom?
description: The third night of the Democratic National Convention was the party’s pitch to be the defender of freedom.
content: Democrats spent the third night of their convention pitching themselves as the party of freedom. In this conversation, my producer Annie Galvin joined me on the show to take a deep look at that messaging. Why do Democrats see an opportunity in this election to seize an idea that Republicans have monopolized for decades? What’s the meaning of “freedom” that Democrats seem to be embracing? And how does this message square with other Democratic Party values, like belief in the ability of government to do good?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: After Some Columbia Donors Pause Gifts, Medical School Gets $400 Million
description: The donation is the largest the medical school has received and comes after other donors pulled back because of Columbia’s response to pro-Palestinian demonstrations.
content: Columbia University’s medical school announced on Thursday that one of its graduates was donating $400 million, the largest gift in the medical school’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: German Support for Ukraine Comes Under New Strains
description: With a budget shortfall for 2025 and evidence mounting that Ukraine blew up natural-gas pipelines between Germany and Russia, German aid to Ukraine is under pressure.
content: BERLIN — The German government has come under increasing pressure at home to roll back its support for Ukraine and push harder for negotiations to try to end its war with Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Urgent Calls for Action on the Climate
description: Readers discuss a science article about potentially irreversible changes. Also: Will Americans elect a felon?; in Governor Walz, echoes of another coach; a revised jobs report; the key to happiness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent Staples
title: The Black Identity in Kamala Harris’s Jamaican Roots
description: The candidate has never felt the need to explain or exploit the story of her family’s ancestors and their experience of slavery.
content: Millions of Black Americans are descended from slaveholders who fathered children with women they owned. White ancestry is especially common among those of us whose families were enslaved in Thomas Jefferson’s Virginia, where the planter class was notorious for its mixed-race children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Close Your Eyes’ Review: The Case of the Unfinished Film
description: For his latest, the Spanish director Victor Erice, known for the classic “The Spirit of the Beehive,” weaves a meta tale of a director looking for an absent actor.
content: A mystery wends through “Close Your Eyes,” a drama in which the past, present and cinema converge. It’s the latest from the Spanish director Victor Erice, who’s best known for the art-cinema paragon “The Spirit of the Beehive” (1973), a dream of a movie about a girl who is deeply troubled by the original “Frankenstein” film. Set around 1940 in the aftermath of the Spanish Civil War, “Beehive” elliptically focuses on a traumatized child and country that, when Erice made this classic, was in the waning years of Franco’s fascist dictatorship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Mountains’ Review: Razing Houses, Building a Future
description: This feature debut from Monica Sorelle observes the tensions in an immigrant family in the Little Haiti neighborhood of Miami.
content: “Mountains,” the feature debut from Monica Sorelle, opens by observing the demolition of a house. In one sense, Sorelle is simply setting the scene. Xavier (Atibon Nazaire), the father in the central family in the film, has a job razing buildings, a role he fulfills without much complaint (although at a crucial moment he sticks up for a co-worker).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Maggie Astor
title: Which Democrats Landed Coveted Slots for the Final Night of the D.N.C.?
description: Vice President Kamala Harris will accept the party’s nomination for president to close out the convention in Chicago.
content: Democrats will bring down the curtain on their convention in Chicago on Thursday night with a showcase for Vice President Kamala Harris and the party’s deep bench, giving marquee speaking slots to governors and candidates from critical swing states before Ms. Harris accepts the party’s nomination for president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg
title: Oprah, Football and Freedom: Highlights From the Democratic Convention
description: On Day 3, Gov. Tim Walz sought to rid the Democrats of their elite image. But another star was Oprah Winfrey, who mesmerized the crowd with an appeal for common sense and decency.
content: It was a night of former presidents and would-be presidents, and the prime-time debut of Gov. Tim Walz, who was cheered by members of the high school football team he once coached. Democrats on Day 3 of their national convention also celebrated Minnesota, the home state of Mr. Walz, with a special tribute to the artist once known as Prince, and an appearance by Senator Amy Klobuchar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anupreeta Das and Sameer Yasir
title: Is India a Safe Place for Women? Another Brutal Killing Raises the Question.
description: The rape and murder of a trainee doctor at her own hospital has brought up, once again, uncomfortable truths about a country that wants to be a global leader.
content: In December 2012, a 23-year-old physiotherapy student boarded a bus in New Delhi a little after 9 p.m., expecting it would take her home. Instead, she was gang-raped and assaulted so viciously with an iron rod that her intestines were damaged. She died days later as India erupted in rage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Powell Faces Economic Crossroads as He Prepares to Speak at Jackson Hole
description: Jerome Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, will deliver remarks as inflation cools and growth holds up — but as labor market weakening threatens to interrupt the soft landing.
content: Two years ago, Jerome H. Powell took the podium at the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City’s annual conference at Jackson Hole in Wyoming and warned America that lowering inflation would require some pain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval, Jody García and Qasim Nauman
title: Guatemala Arrests 7 Over Deaths of 53 Migrants in Texas
description: The arrests included the leader of the group involved in the 2022 smuggling operation. He faces extradition to the United States, while the others face charges in Guatemala.
content: A man accused of taking part in a human-smuggling operation that led to the deaths of 53 migrants in Texas has been indicted by a federal grand jury in one of the deadliest episodes involving migrants on the southern border of the United States, federal prosecutors said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: Why Too Few Homes Get Built in the U.S.
description: We explore why it could take a long time to fix — and what policymakers are doing about it.
content: The housing crunch has been well documented in high-cost big cities, where rents and mortgages break the bank. Now it has moved into the rest of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Russia Opens New Cases Against Journalists Who Covered Ukrainian Incursion
description: Moscow said it was investigating three more reporters, including a CNN correspondent, who crossed into Russian territory to cover the fighting.
content: Russia on Thursday announced that it had opened a criminal case against a CNN correspondent and two Ukrainian reporters on charges of entering the country illegally while reporting on an incursion into the Kursk region by Ukraine’s armed forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Igielnik
title: Kennedy’s Decision Is Unlikely to Change the Race Significantly
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s backers say they are less likely to vote, and recent polls disagree on whether Mr. Kennedy was drawing more votes from Donald Trump or Kamala Harris.
content: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s decision on Friday to suspend his presidential bid comes after his poll numbers had fallen to the level of a run-of-the-mill third-party candidate, after initially showing notably strong support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annette Gordon-Reed
title: The Ascent of Kamala Harris Should Not Come as a Surprise
description: Ms. Harris’s ascent should not come as a big surprise, both because of who we are now (and have been historically) and because of who she is.
content: As the Democratic Party’s nominee for president of the United States, Vice President Kamala Harris has generated a remarkable level of enthusiasm almost from the moment President Joe Biden endorsed her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 439
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, Aug. 23, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Maya King, Mitra Taj, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Kennedy Is Expected to Drop Out, and Revised Data Shows Job Market Cracks
description: Plus, the Mennonites making the Amazon home.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Jury in New Orleans Awards $1 Million to Teen Raped by Police Officer
description: The officer, Rodney Vicknair, who died in prison this year, met the girl while taking her to a hospital after she was sexually assaulted by another man, prosecutors said.
content: The city of New Orleans must pay $1 million to a teenager who was groomed and raped in 2020 by a former police officer who presented himself as a mentor to the girl, a federal jury decided on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Weiner
title: Jennifer Lopez Is Becoming an Elizabeth Taylor for a New Generation
description: “I resented my fame,” Taylor said, “until I realized I could use it.”
content: Nothing gold can stay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Theater Breaks Ties With Ivo van Hove After Report on Bullying
description: An investigation found that a “culture of fear” had developed at the International Theater Amsterdam during the years when the star director led the company.
content: The International Theater Amsterdam said on Wednesday that it had cut ties with Ivo van Hove, the Tony-winning director who led the company for more than 20 years. The breakup was announced just weeks after a report said that a “culture of fear” had developed under van Hove’s leadership and that he allowed bullying to go unchecked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Oprah Winfrey, in a Convention Debut, Calls Harris ‘the Best of America’
description: The surprise appearance by the television legend was closely held by Democratic organizers. Ms. Winfrey even rehearsed her speech wearing sunglasses and a face mask.
content: The television legend Oprah Winfrey returned to prime time on Wednesday in a surprise appearance at the Democratic National Convention, calling on Americans to choose “optimism over cynicism” and “inclusion over retribution” as she endorsed the candidacy of Vice President Kamala Harris, whose life story Ms. Winfrey deemed “the best of America.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Louise Snyder
title: Chrystul Kizer Got 11 Years in Prison for Killing Her Abuser. This Is Justice?
description: What her case illustrates about the sexism and racism that corrupt our criminal justice system.
content: In 2018, a Black teenager named Chrystul Kizer shot and killed a 34-year-old white man named Randall Volar III, who had sexually abused and trafficked her starting when she was 16 years old; she was 17 at the time of the killing. This week, a Wisconsin judge sentenced her to 11 years in prison, with another five under supervision. Rather than serving justice, her case illustrates with searing clarity the sexism and racism that corrupt our criminal justice system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan
title: Missouri Court Halts Deal to Spare Prisoner From Execution
description: The State Supreme Court said the trial had to hold a hearing before accepting a deal that would give the man a sentence of life without parole.
content: In a suburban St. Louis courtroom on Wednesday, it appeared that Marcellus Williams would be spared execution after the local prosecutor’s office raised questions about his guilt and agreed to a prison sentence of life without parole.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma
title: In a Likely Overture to China, Nepal Lifts Ban on TikTok
description: The move signaled that Nepal’s new prime minister, who has cultivated ties with China, would continue on that path.
content: The new prime minister of Nepal, K.P. Sharma Oli, on Thursday overturned a ban on TikTok that his predecessor imposed in November, an apparent sign that the veteran politician intended to strengthen the country’s relations with China, its northern neighbor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Convention Insider: Wes Moore Is in Constant Demand
description: For the governor of Maryland and his staff, logistics — and local cuisine — can be a challenge.
content: Wes Moore, the Democratic governor of Maryland, was still shaking hands as his body man began to lead him out of the afternoon cocktail party at an Italian restaurant above the Chicago River. Flanked by a retinue of aides and security officials, he and his wife, Dawn, left through a side door and made their way into a narrow hallway, past waiting trays of meatballs and lamb chops, into a prep kitchen — wrong way, everybody turn around — and, finally, into a capacious service elevator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: What I’m reading: A ‘Book of the Century’ I’d Somehow Missed
description: “The Last Samurai,” which has nothing to do with the Tom Cruise movie of the same name, is as good as everyone says.
content: Until a few weeks ago, when The New York Times's list of the best books of this century reminded me of the oversight, I had never read “The Last Samurai,” by Helen DeWitt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Caitlin O'Keefe and Elisa Gutierrez
title: It’s Kamala Harris’s Party Now. What’s Different?
description: Senator Elizabeth Warren, U.A.W. president Shawn Fain and Chicago mayor Brandon Johnson on the passing of the torch.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris speaks at her convention tonight, formalizing her rapid ascent to the top of the Democratic ticket and capping a very unusual path to the nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden
title: Mindy Kaling Goes From ‘Cooking With Kamala’ to Hosting Her Convention
description: Ms. Kaling, like Vice President Kamala Harris, is Indian American. They once cooked masala dosa together in a 2019 YouTube video.
content: In late November 2019, as her once promising 2020 presidential campaign was faltering, Kamala Harris appeared in a cooking video with the actress and comedian Mindy Kaling. A week later, Ms. Harris quit the race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘I’ll Be Your Mirror’ Review: A Mourning Journey
description: This visually elegant indie follows a soft-spoken Swiss widow visiting Japan.
content: A visually elegant drama by the writer-director Bradley Rust Gray, “I’ll Be Your Mirror” spins a gossamer-fine story about grief — about the struggle to live fully again when the tragedies of the past still exist in your bones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Second-Largest Diamond Ever Found Is Discovered in Botswana
description: The diamond was unearthed using new technology, and miners hope it will bring back luster to a struggling industry.
content: The diamond was so large that it obscured the face of Botswana’s president as he held it up for closer inspection on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 22, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Aug. 22, 2024.
content: An article on Wednesday about a conflict of interest in the decision to give the bronze medal to Romanian gymnast, Ana Barbosu, over America’s Jordan Chiles, misstated the name of the institution that first published details of the case. It is the International Institute for Conflict Prevention and Resolution, not the International Institute for Conflict Resolution and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurtis Lee
title: Farm Workers Union Battles California Grower Owned by Democratic Donors
description: Wonderful Nurseries, owned by Stewart and Lynda Resnick, has sued the state to overturn a labor organizing law championed by the United Farm Workers.
content: The allegations ricocheted through the agricultural fields and into a Central Valley courthouse, where one of California’s most powerful companies and an iconic union were trading charges of deception and coercion in a fight over worker representation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Rick Steves, TV Travel Guide, Says He Has Prostate Cancer
description: Mr. Steves said the cancer had not spread and he will travel to France for work before having surgery next month.
content: Rick Steves, a travel writer who has built an empire of guidebooks, radio shows and television programs that focus on Europe, said on Wednesday that he had recently been diagnosed with prostate cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: The Meaning — and Power — of Kamala Harris’s Smile
description: Hers is a deliberate sparkle. Not unlike … Ronald Reagan’s.
content: I’m reluctant to write about Kamala Harris’s smile because I’m going to get all gushy and mushy about it, and the Harris lovefest is a jammed jamboree without need of another journalist. She’s enjoying more than a routine political honeymoon; she’s in the priciest suite on the poshest cruise ship sailing through a tropical paradise where coconuts tumble juicily from their trees into her aloe-moistened hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis and Ian Austen
title: What a Prolonged Rail Shutdown in Canada Would Mean for Trade
description: Rail labor disruptions in Canada tend to be brief, but a prolonged stoppage could have hurt farmers, automakers and other businesses.
content: Late Thursday, the Canadian government ordered arbitration between the railroads and the rail workers’ union, a move that will end the shutdown. Read the latest coverage here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck, Nicholas Nehamas and Reid J. Epstein
title: Tim Walz, Accepting V.P. Nomination, Tells Democrats to ‘Leave It on the Field’
description: Completing his transformation into a party leader, Mr. Walz played up his Midwestern roots and his time as a football coach. “It’s the fourth quarter,” he said. “We’re down a field goal.”
content: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota offered himself as a bridge to disillusioned Americans who regard the Democratic Party as a bastion of coastal elitism, in a high-stakes address formally accepting the vice-presidential nomination on Wednesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison and Jeanna Smialek
title: Trump May Claim Credit for Stock Surges, but the Reality Is Far More Complicated
description: On Wall Street, claims that a president is responsible for the fate of the stock market are largely dismissed as bluster.
content: As president, Donald J. Trump continually took credit for a rising stock market, citing it as evidence that his economic policies were enriching Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: An Economic Soft Landing, or a Rockies Letdown?
description: Investors are anxiously awaiting Jerome Powell’s policy speech at a symposium in Jackson Hole, Wyo., on Friday, as labor data suggests the economy is slowing.
content: After a tumultuous stretch, the S&P 500 is tantalizingly close to record territory as investors see the Fed at a pivotal juncture in its efforts to pull off the once unthinkable: a soft landing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Convention Insider: This Union Leader Is a Hug Machine
description: Lee Saunders, the president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, is in high spirits at a convention where union leaders have been treated well.
content: Lee Saunders is a hugger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Garrison Keillor on Tim Walz, ‘Minnesota Nice’ and Small-Town Appeal
description: Mr. Keillor said the vice-presidential candidate, a hunter and a football coach, used authenticity to win his congressional district.
content: Addressing the Democratic National Convention in Chicago on Wednesday night, Tim Walz, the party’s vice-presidential nominee, referred to the state which he has served as a congressman and, since 2019, as governor: “In Minnesota, we respect our neighbors and the personal choices they make. And even if we wouldn’t make those same choices for ourselves, we’ve got a golden rule: Mind your own damn business.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: Convention Insider: The Unexpected Reappearance of John Edwards
description: Mr. Edwards was once a rising star, but his political career evaporated amid scandal. And yet, there he was, reconnecting with old associates at the Democratic convention.
content: Of all the curious characters spotted bouncing around inside the Democrats’ big tent this week — the influencers, the ex-Trump White House press secretary, Lil Jon — the most curious of all might have been John Edwards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Janfaza
title: Signs of Taylor Swift on Wrists at the Democratic Convention
description: Friendship bracelets, after being adopted by the pop star’s fans, have now been embraced by convention attendees as a way to build community.
content: In the weeks leading up to the Democratic National Convention, a surge of enthusiasm for the party’s new ticket of Vice President Kamala Harris and Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota brought fresh energy to their campaign events. Some were set to music by Beyoncé and had attendees dancing in the crowds, giving them a bit of a concert-like feel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa and Alyce McFadden
title: Trump Wants to Distance Himself From Project 2025. Democrats Are Trying Not to Let Him.
description: The conservative policy proposal has been front and center at the Democratic convention this week, as Democrats look to tie the controversial document to the former president.
content: Kenan Thompson, the longest-tenured cast member in “Saturday Night Live” history, strode on to the stage on Wednesday night with an oversize book and thumped it heavily onto the lectern: an exaggerated version of Project 2025, a controversial set of conservative policy proposals outlining an agenda for the next Republican president that Democrats have brandished all week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Celebrities Make Last-Ditch Effort to Save Elizabeth Street Garden
description: The city plans to turn a sanctuary on the edge of Little Italy into housing for older New Yorkers. Robert De Niro, Martin Scorsese and Patti Smith pleaded on the garden’s behalf.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll look at a last-minute effort by three celebrities who oppose the city’s efforts to reclaim a garden in NoLIta for an affordable housing project. We’ll also get details on the state attorney general’s response to Donald Trump’s appeal of his $454 million civil fraud judgment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack and Nate Schweber
title: The Emotional Support Parrots vs. the Co-op Board
description: Three pet parrots at a Manhattan apartment building irritated their neighbors, who moved to evict them and their owner. The owner took the neighbors to court and was awarded $165,000 in damages.
content: For almost 20 years, a group of parrots and their owner lived at the Rutherford, a co-op apartment building in the ritzy Gramercy Park neighborhood of Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Peter Dykstra, Pioneering CNN Climate Journalist, Dies at 67
description: A former Greenpeace official, he drew on his command of environmental subjects to persuade his bosses at the cable channel to cover climate issues.
content: Peter Dykstra, an environmental activist turned journalist who was known for his sardonic wit, once asked Senator James M. Inhofe of Oklahoma, Congress’s most aggressive denier of climate science, for an interview, to take place in 2034.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: What to Expect on the Convention’s Last Night
description: Vice President Kamala Harris is set to take the stage to formally accept her party’s nomination to be president.
content: The Democratic National Convention will conclude Thursday night with what is, by any measure, the marquee event of the week: when Vice President Kamala Harris takes the stage to formally accept her party’s nomination to be president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Matt Berry Is Afraid of Heights, Not Comedy
description: His performance as a debauched vampire in “What We Do in the Shadows” earned him an Emmy nod. It has also often had him dangling 50 feet off the ground.
content: Voting is underway for the 76th Primetime Emmys, and this week we are talking to several first-time Emmy nominees. The awards will be presented Sept. 15 on ABC.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Put Kids’ Interests First, This Librarian Insists
description: Working in a Louisiana middle school has made Amanda Jones a culture warrior, a process she describes in “That Librarian: The Fight Against Book Banning in America.”
content: What books are on your night stand?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Convention Insider: Cory Booker Never Stops
description: The New Jersey senator is giving speeches, posing for selfies, schmoozing with delegates. How many breakfasts has he attended at the D.N.C.? Fifteen so far.
content: When Senator Cory Booker of New Jersey arrived at the Pennsylvania delegation breakfast on Thursday, he had already taken a dozen selfies, missed three elevators and fist-bumped a security guard. He was wiping sweat off his head with a table napkin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Genevieve Glatsky
title: Venezuela’s Supreme Court, Loyal to Maduro, Rules Him Election Winner
description: The court did not share voting data to back up its decision despite demands from Venezuelans and international election observers that the government produce evidence of his victory.
content: Venezuela’s highest court ruled on Thursday that the country’s authoritarian leader, Nicolás Maduro, won the July 28 presidential election, despite overwhelming evidence that Mr. Maduro’s opponent garnered the most votes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Convention Insider: Jasmine Crockett Would Like to Introduce Herself
description: The representative from Texas, who overcame a “pit in my stomach” onstage this week, is emerging as an influential surrogate for the Harris campaign.
content: Representative Jasmine Crockett, Democrat of Texas, doesn’t get nervous. Not when she spars with her Republican colleagues in committee hearings. Not when she questions the point of what she sees as fruitless impeachment inquiries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: End the Meal With Dessert (At Another Restaurant)
description: Sometimes restaurant dessert menus can be lacking. Luckily, there’s always a better option not too far away.
content: If you’ve read this newsletter or column (hello print readers!) long enough then you know that I write about dessert in an almost obsessive way. If you’re the type of person who craves something sweet after dinner or a 3 p.m. pickup in the form of a warm cookie, then you’re my type of person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Michael J. de la Merced
title: Lynch Yacht Sinking Off Sicily Proves as Baffling as It Is Tragic
description: As bodies were recovered, the authorities and experts wondered how a $40 million, stable and secure vessel could have sunk so quickly.
content: Two months after being cleared in a bruising legal battle over fraud charges, the British tech mogul Mike Lynch celebrated his freedom with a cruise. He invited his family, friends and part of his legal team on board his luxury sailing yacht, a majestic 180-foot vessel named Bayesian after the mathematical theorem around which he had built his empire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Bible Teaching in Every Classroom? In Oklahoma, Few Signs It’s Happening.
description: Oklahoma’s schools superintendent announced in June that every teacher in the state would be expected to teach the Bible. As schools open, there’s little evidence they have changed their curriculums or teaching.
content: Three days after Oklahoma’s state superintendent, Ryan Walters, directed every teacher in the state’s public schools to teach the Bible this summer, he walked onstage to a standing ovation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Bilal Shbair
title: The War in Gaza Is Making Thousands of Orphans
description: Extended families, hospital staff and volunteers are stepping in to care for Gaza’s many newly orphaned children, some of whom are injured, traumatized and haunted by memories of their parents.
content: The boys are aching to see their parents again. They are convinced it will happen as soon as they can go back to Gaza City, where they were growing up before the war bulldozed that life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty and Jamie Kelter Davis
title: What Kalamazoo (Yes, Kalamazoo) Reveals About the Nation’s Housing Crisis
description: A decade ago, the city — and all of Michigan — had too many houses. Now it has a shortage. The shift there explains today’s costly housing market in the rest of the country.
content: For years, when Michigan politicians talked about the state’s housing problem, they were referring to a surplus: too many run-down houses, stripped of valuable copper, sitting empty and blighting neighborhoods. Now the message has flipped. In her State of the State address this year, Gov. Gretchen Whitmer lamented the housing shortage and landed one of her biggest applause lines with, “The rent is too damn high, and we don’t have enough damn housing. So our response is simple: ‘Build, baby, build!’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: How Kamala Harris Is Preparing for the Biggest Speech of Her Life
description: Her convention address on Thursday will tell the story of her middle-class upbringing, cast the 2024 race as the future versus the past and appeal to patriotism.
content: Kamala Harris often leans on a favored phrase to focus her team before beginning an important project: “What business are we trying to accomplish here?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Theodore Schleifer
title: Crypto Lobbyist Charged With Breaking Campaign Finance Rules
description: The charges against Michelle Bond, a former head of a crypto industry trade group, are part of the continuing legal fallout from the collapse of the FTX crypto exchange.
content: A former cryptocurrency industry lobbyist was charged with campaign finance fraud on Thursday, the latest criminal prosecution to stem from the collapse of the FTX crypto exchange.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Bergeron and Andre D. Wagner
title: Cash Cobain Is Steering Drill Rap’s Sexy Swerve
description: The rapper and producer’s lusty rhymes and unorthodox samples have made hits for hip-hop’s most lascivious luminaries. With a new album, he aims to join them.
content: Drill music hasn’t always been this fun. The subgenre’s ominous beats and menacing lyrics infiltrated mainstream hip-hop over a decade ago, but its ascendant stars have been stalled by violence, police surveillance and the flattening effect of at-home copycats. Cash Cobain, the 26-year-old breakout rapper and producer from the Bronx, is helping to raise its trajectory. With lusty rhymes and unorthodox samples, he’s become a central figure of “sexy drill,” a more lascivious offshoot, and one that has tilted the sound of rap nationally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Seth Meyers Approves of the Obamas Dissing Donald Trump
description: The “Late Night” host remarked that former President Barack Obama burned Donald Trump “without even saying a word” on Day 2 of the D.N.C.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: What’s Vexing Donald Trump Now? Kamala Harris’s Looks.
description: From the vice president’s looks to the “angel” judge at his trial, the former president can’t help commenting on the appearance of others — especially in relation to himself.
content: Of all the issues that seemingly preoccupy the mind of Donald J. Trump — his perceived persecutions, the evil of his enemies, the size of the rallies — there is one that may be the most consistent: other people’s looks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J Wortham
title: The Afterlives of Audre Lorde
description: The feminist thinker is celebrated as a prophet of empowerment and self-care. A new biography shows how she saw our future even more keenly.
content: Even if you don’t know who Audre Lorde is, you’ve probably encountered her ideas in the world or, at the very least, scrolled past them on social media. Lines from her poems and essays are just as likely to appear in an Instagram post as on a protest sign or in a pamphlet for an academic conference: “We were never meant to survive.” “The master’s tools will never dismantle the master’s house.” “Your silence will not protect you.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: The U.S. Open Is Free This Week. Yes, Really.
description: “Fan Week” draws thousands during the qualifying rounds of the tournament, no tickets necessary. You still have to pay for the cocktails, of course.
content: Long lines of limousines stretching out at the V.I.P. entrance. A-list celebrities in luxury boxes flashing on the giant video screens to fans who pay $4,000 for a fifth-row seat and sip $23 Honey Deuce cocktails. It’s the United States Open, one of the glitziest, most expensive and most popular sporting events on the calendar, and it begins on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: Counting All the Fish in the Sea May Be Even Trickier Than Scientists Thought
description: A new study suggests that estimates of the health of the world’s fisheries may be too optimistic.
content: Counting the number of fish in the ocean may well be one of science’s toughest jobs. It also produces a crucial tool governments use to protect marine ecosystems that feed millions of people across the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Arkansas Supreme Court Denies Bid to Get Abortion Measure on the Ballot
description: A majority on the state Supreme Court sided with the secretary of state, who had rejected a citizen group’s petition for failing to submit some of the necessary paperwork.
content: The Arkansas Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that an abortion-rights amendment was ineligible for the November ballot, agreeing with state officials that organizers of the effort had failed to submit all of the required paperwork.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,161
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for August 23, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Geri Taylor, a Voice for Alzheimer’s, Is Dead at 81
description: She turned her diagnosis into a command to live life passionately, leading to a 12-page New York Times profile and a new career as a public speaker.
content: Geri Taylor, whose openhearted disclosures about the ravages of Alzheimer’s were so striking that they made her a public spokeswoman for people with the disease, died on Aug. 4 in Danbury, Conn. She was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Harris Leans on Memory of Her Mother, as She Reintroduces Herself
description: The definitional power of parenthood has been an unofficial theme of the Democratic convention this week. And Shyamala Gopalan Harris, the vice president’s mother, is a main character.
content: In 1958, a young graduate student moved to the United States from her native India because she wanted to find a cure for breast cancer. She fell in love, got married and had two daughters. She named her eldest Kamala, a Sanskrit name meaning lotus flower.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: A TikTok Cucumber Craze Has Iceland in a Pickle
description: Icelandic cooks, eager to try the latest social media trend, are amused and a little surprised by their empty produce aisles.
content: “Sometimes,” the TikTok star known as “Cucumber Guy” intones at the start of his videos, “you need to eat an entire cucumber.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salamishah Tillet
title: The Meaning Behind Beyoncé’s ‘Freedom,’ the Harris Campaign Anthem
description: The song is a driving force behind Vice President Kamala Harris’s latest campaign ad. But the song’s origins offer deeper significance for a candidate hoping to make history.
content: Since Kamala’s Harris’s first appearance at campaign headquarters a month ago, the rousing strains of Beyoncé’s “Freedom” have been the candidate’s spirited anthem, blaring under the campaign ads and ahead of Harris’s speeches. The song, from the 2016 visual album “Lemonade,” builds momentum with each verse and features a chorus that is a striking call: “I break chains all by myself/Won’t let my freedom rot in hell/Hey! I’ma keep running/’Cause a winner don’t quit on themselves.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Trump Warms to Kennedy and Belittles Walz in Fox News Appearance
description: Donald J. Trump said he would welcome the endorsement of Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who is expected to end his presidential campaign.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump offered a glowing assessment of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. on Thursday amid reports that the political scion would end his troubled independent presidential campaign and was considering endorsing him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: ‘Blink Twice’ Review: Nightmare Island
description: The director Zoë Kravitz creates an uneasy atmosphere in her abduction horror flick, starring Naomi Ackie and Channing Tatum.
content: For a film like “Blink Twice” to land its horror-stained commentary on sexual assault and cancel culture as well as class and race, it would need a director capable of pushing beyond basic social politics. In her debut feature, Zoë Kravitz is not that director.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Between the Temples’ Review: A Widower Walks Into a Bar
description: And meets his former music teacher, upending his life, in Nathan Silver’s touching comedy, starring Jason Schwartzman and Carol Kane.
content: Ben Gottlieb — the touchingly soulful hero of the soulful, delightfully tetchy “Between the Temples” — is a mess. He needs a haircut and a shave; he could do with better-fitting clothes. He’s having problems at work. He also lives in his family’s basement, that much-derided refuge of the eternal man-child and terminal loser. Yet because the filmmaker Nathan Silver has an appreciation for life’s ironies and likes putting a topspin on his comedy, Ben lives with both his mother and stepmother. He lives, in other words, in his mothers’ basement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: A Great Year for Movies. The Best Year to Start Writing About Them.
description: At the box office 25 years ago, hits like “Runaway Bride,” “The Sixth Sense” and “Bowfinger” hint at the abundance that overwhelmed a young critic.
content: One thing to love about time is how liberating it can be. I, for instance, am at liberty to look at the Top 10 movies for the weekend of Aug. 20, 1999 — when “The Sixth Sense,” in its third week out, began its monopoly of the chart — and declare “The Thomas Crown Affair” the best of the lot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Mike Lynch, Tech Mogul Acquitted of Fraud, Dies at 59
description: The British entrepreneur was found not guilty of fraud charges in the sale of his company to Hewlett-Packard. He was celebrating his acquittal when his yacht sank off the coast of Sicily.
content: Mike Lynch, a British software mogul who was once celebrated as a top technology leader — only to spend more than a decade defending himself against accusations that he orchestrated one of the biggest frauds in Silicon Valley history — died on Monday after his yacht sank off the coast of Sicily. He was 59.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Thailand Confirms Its First Case of New, Deadlier Mpox Version
description: The Clade Ib version of the virus had not been detected outside Africa until last week, when a case in Sweden raised concerns about a wider outbreak.
content: Health officials in Thailand said on Thursday that they had confirmed a case of the version of mpox that prompted the World Health Organization to declare a global health emergency. It’s the second time that the new and deadlier version has been found outside Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Yu
title: ‘The Crow’ Review: Resurrected and It Feels So Bad
description: Hoping to skate by off moody vibes, this revamp of “The Crow” comic book series seems derived from a flattened, Hot Topic image of the hero.
content: In the long and winding road it took to finally get to “The Crow” — with some 15 years of recasts, rewrites, and director switches — the one constant that has remained is that this version would not be a remake of the 1994 film of the same name. It would, the mantra went, instead be a reimagining of the original comic book series by James O’Barr about a man, resurrected from the dead, enacting vengeance on the small-time gangsters who killed him and his fiancée.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Taylor Swift Says She Felt ‘Fear’ and ‘Guilt’ After Canceled Vienna Shows
description: The three stops in Austria on the pop star’s Eras Tour were canceled after the authorities discovered a terrorist plot targeting the concerts.
content: Taylor Swift said Wednesday that she was devastated by the cancellation of her Eras Tour concerts in Vienna, adding that the terrorist plot that had targeted her shows there had filled her “with a new sense of fear, and a tremendous amount of guilt because so many people had planned on coming.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: A Recipe for When You Want a Sandwich but Should Maybe Eat a Salad
description: Behold: Kia Damon’s easy and satisfying chicken gyro chopped salad.
content: When I’m really hungry but know I should eat something green because breakfast was two chocolate chip cookies and lunch was cold pizza, a fun dinner game I play is “Will it salad?” The premise is simple: Can I turn the thing I really want to eat (tacos, a bagel and cream cheese, falafel, more pizza) into a salad?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Abbie VanSickle
title: Supreme Court Allows Arizona to Enforce, for Now, Law Tightening New Voter Registrations
description: But the justices kept blocking a provision that bars already-registered residents from voting by mail or for president until they prove their citizenship.
content: The Supreme Court on Thursday allowed Arizona, at least for now, to toughen some voting requirements, saying that people registering to vote before the coming election must show proof of citizenship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise and Shawn Hubler
title: Google Joins $250 Million Deal to Support Newsrooms in California
description: The agreement includes $70 million from the state, which needs legislative approval. Some lawmakers objected, calling for a more comprehensive solution with tech companies.
content: Google, a news industry trade group and key California lawmakers announced a first-in-the-nation agreement on Wednesday aimed at shoring up newsrooms in the state with as much as $250 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Alcorn
title: How to Find the Right Oncologist for You
description: After a cancer diagnosis, it’s one of the most important decisions you’ll make.
content: After a career as a golf professional in southeastern New Mexico, Doug Lyle, 76, decided he had somewhere better to be than on the course: spending time with his new grandchild. Then this summer, just as he was settling into retirement, he learned he had prostate cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: In the Wake of Tragedy, CrossFit Faces an Identity Crisis
description: CrossFit has found success as a training exercise for everyone. But the CrossFit Games may tell a different story.
content: The atmosphere at the closing ceremony of the CrossFit Games last week at the Dickies Arena, a 14,000-seat venue in Fort Worth, was decidedly solemn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: A Deep Dive on Dip for Dinner
description: Starting with Ali Slagle’s fresh tomato and yogurt dip, a new two-step recipe with sweet acidity and garlicky bite.
content: The promise of dip for dinner is, often, the promise of no cooking at all. And when it’s hot out, I haven’t slept enough, I’m in a rush or some lethal combination of all three, I want that promise kept.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim, Abu Bakr Bashir and Isabel Kershner
title: Israel Orders New Evacuations, Forcing Gazans to Flee Again
description: As the Israeli military ordered people to leave parts of central and southern Gaza, a surgeon said that hospital workers were asking, “Where can we go, what are we going to do?”
content: The Israeli military issued new evacuation orders in the Gaza Strip on Thursday, forcing more Palestinians to flee their homes and shelters, as the United States and others tried to salvage sputtering talks that could ease regional tensions and stop the 10-month war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Crew Rescued, but Oil Tanker Attacked in Red Sea Is an ‘Environmental Hazard’
description: The incident appeared to be the most serious in weeks involving commercial shipping off Yemen’s coast. It was not clear whether any oil was leaking.
content: The crew of a Greek-flagged oil tanker that came under gun and missile attack in the Red Sea has been rescued after being forced to evacuate the vessel into a lifeboat, a European Union naval mission said on Thursday. The attack appears to have been the most serious in weeks against commercial shipping off the coast of Yemen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Lozada
title: The Shifting Convictions of Kamala Harris
description: The vice president says she wants to prosecute the case against Trump, but we are still trying to figure out what kind of prosecutor she was.
content: Supporters of Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign like to note that their candidate can “prosecute the case” against Donald Trump, a felon and recidivist Republican nominee. Speaking at rallies, the vice president has embraced the message, recalling that as a former courtroom prosecutor, district attorney and state attorney general, she took on all manner of predators, fraudsters and cheaters. “So, hear me when I say,” Harris tells the rapturous crowds of Insert State Here, “I know Donald Trump’s type!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Tough Nut to Crack
description: Brad Wiegmann’s puzzle theme is hard to pronounce.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Fact-Checking Kamala Harris on the Campaign Trail
description: We assessed some of the vice president’s talking points about her opponent.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris is set to accept the Democratic nomination for president on Thursday night, capping an extraordinary month in which her ascent to the top of her party’s ticket has upended the 2024 race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Once a Rising Star, Eric Adams Is Sidelined at the Democratic Convention
description: New York City’s mayor, who has criticized the White House over the migrant crisis, did not receive a speaking slot at this week’s convention in Chicago.
content: Three years after Mayor Eric Adams declared that as a tough-on-crime moderate, he represented “the future of the Democratic Party,” he was largely missing from the Democratic National Convention in Chicago this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: Why Democrats Stopped Asking if a Woman Could Win the White House
description: Democratic women say much has changed since Hillary Clinton lost her bid for the White House in 2016 — and lessons have been learned.
content: The first time Kamala Harris ran for president, in 2019, one question dogged her and the handful of others running to be the first female president: Can a woman win?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: The Hard Way Into the U.S. Open: The Battle of the Qualifiers
description: Thirty-two spots remain unclaimed in the tournament, and the math is as brutal as it is simple. Win three matches, and you’re in.
content: Michael Zheng shifted uncomfortably on the base line of Court 13 at the U.S. Open, an outdoor court he had played on as a boy in an elite training program. But this time there was much more at stake, with hundreds of fans crammed in on all four sides, chanting, “Let’s go, Michael,” for the local favorite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Russian Attitudes About Putin Might Be Shifting
description: Negative remarks on social media have increased since Ukrainian troops launched an incursion, according to a firm that tracks Russian attitudes.
content: Negative feelings about President Vladimir V. Putin have appeared to increase across Russia since Ukrainian troops pushed into Russian territory two weeks ago, according to a firm that tracks attitudes in the country by analyzing social media and other internet postings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canadian Government Orders Arbitration and End to Rail Freight Shutdown
description: The shutdown had threatened to disrupt trade with the United States and other countries, as well as cause serious economic consequences in Canada.
content: Less than 17 hours after almost all rail freight traffic in Canada came to a standstill Thursday following a lockout by the country’s two main rail companies of 10,000 employees, the federal government told a labor board to end the shutdown and ordered arbitration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Former Oath Keepers Lawyer Pleads Guilty to Tampering With Jan. 6 Evidence
description: Kellye SoRelle admitted to telling members of the far-right group to illegally delete their text messages after the mob attack.
content: The former lawyer for the Oath Keepers militia pleaded guilty on Wednesday to advising members of the far-right group to illegally delete their text messages after the violent mob attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps and Rachel Nostrant
title: Veterans Say Attacks on Candidates’ Service Records Are a Turnoff
description: Many veterans say that disparaging an opponent’s military service, as JD Vance has done with Tim Walz, is unhelpful, and they want to hear about current issues instead.
content: Republicans backing the Trump campaign have kept up their attacks on the military career of Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota during the Democratic convention, accusing him, among other things, of having abandoned his fellow soldiers by retiring from the National Guard to run for Congress in 2006, months before his unit deployed to Iraq.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Russia Pushes Forward in Ukraine’s East as Kursk Offensive Slows
description: The Ukrainians must defend a critical front in their country’s east, including the city of Pokrovsk, while trying to press forward in western Russia.
content: More than two weeks into its surprise offensive in western Russia, Ukraine’s advance has slowed, with its troops making only marginal gains around territory they already control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: The Starbucks C.E.O.’s New Commute: 1,000 Miles on a Corporate Jet
description: Brian Niccol, the incoming head of Starbucks, has a C-suite perk that has raised eyebrows in post-pandemic office culture: an interstate commute on a plane.
content: There is perhaps nothing that unites the foot soldiers of capitalism like the universally agitating experience of commuting: sitting in traffic for hours; getting sweaty on (often-delayed) subways; suffering through mediocre bike lanes and threats of congestion pricing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Opinion
title: ‘O-prah! O-prah! Damn, She’s Good’: The Best and Worst Moments From Night 3 of the Democratic Convention
description: What our columnists and contributors thought of speeches by Oprah Winfrey, Bill Clinton and Tim Walz.
content: Welcome to Opinion’s commentary for Night 3 of the Democratic National Convention. In this special feature, Times Opinion writers rate the evening on a scale of 0 to 10: 0 means the night was a disaster for Kamala Harris; 10 means it could lead to a big polling bump. Here’s what our columnists and contributors thought of the event, which included speeches by Oprah Winfrey, Josh Shapiro, Bill Clinton and Tim Walz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Fund-Raiser for Jan. 6 Defendants Will Be Held at Trump’s Golf Club
description: Mr. Trump is said to not be attending the event, although an invitation lists him as an “invited guest speaker.” It will be held two months before Election Day.
content: A nonprofit organization that supports people charged in connection with the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol is set to hold a legal fund-raiser for the rioters next month at former President Donald J. Trump’s private golf club in Bedminster, N.J.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Convention Insider: Bernie Sanders Is in on the Joke
description: Mr. Sanders, the curmudgeonly senator from Vermont, is exuding something like optimism about the future of the progressive movement.
content: A remarkable sighting has been reported on the sidelines of the Democratic National Convention in Chicago. Not Beyoncé. Not Taylor Swift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nuwer
title: Psychedelic Drugs May Give a Glimpse Into Near-Death Experiences
description: A survey revealed similarities between these two altered states of consciousness.
content: One person felt a sensation of “slowly floating into the air” as images flashed around. Another recalled “the most profound sense of love and peace,” unlike anything experienced before. Consciousness became a “foreign entity” to another whose “whole sense of reality disappeared.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni and Johnatan Reiss
title: Autopsies of 6 Bodies Recovered From Gaza Reveal Bullets, Advocacy Group for Hostage Families Says
description: The assertion raised new questions about how the Israeli hostages died. An Israeli military spokesperson stressed that it was too soon to determine whether gunshot wounds were the cause of death.
content: A group representing relatives of hostages taken in the Oct. 7 attack on Israel said on Thursday that autopsies showed “bullets were found in the bodies” of six captives Israeli troops recovered from an underground tunnel in southern Gaza, raising questions about how they died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: ‘Pachinko’ Is a Gorgeous Epic of Love and Struggle
description: Based on the novel by Min Jin Lee, this thoughtful series about a Korean family across generations returns to Apple TV+ for a second season.
content: Adapted from the acclaimed novel by Min Jin Lee, the Apple TV+ drama “Pachinko” spans decades in the life of a Korean family, beginning first in 1915 under Japanese colonial rule in Korea and later in Japan, where the family’s ambitions bump up against ingrained prejudice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Soller
title: In Majorca, a One-Room Home With Sheep for Neighbors
description: How a couple transformed a tumbledown shepherd’s hut into a spare but functional retreat with views of the Balearic Sea.
content: Long before artists started arriving some two hundred years ago in the sunny hillside villages of Majorca, there were olive trees — nearly infinite quantities, which some oil producers date to the 15th century. The tangled groves still weave throughout the Tramuntana mountain range that hugs the Balearic island’s northwest coast, as essential to the scenery as the dusty cliffs that divebomb into the sea. In the middle is Sóller, a lazy coastal town, in a valley inhabited since 4,000 B.C., from which you can drive inland and lose yourself in the solitude of this singular landscape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Yan
title: Where Are New Apartments Being Built in the U.S.?
description: All over, with 500,000 new units expected to be completed in 2024.
content: In July, the median U.S. home sale price slipped slightly from a record high of $442,389 as interest rates fell. At the same time, the number of sales reached its lowest-ever July level, according to Redfin. All evidence indicates that more Americans will continue to rent, at least for now. But where will they live?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Duehren
title: What We Know About Kamala Harris’s $5 Trillion Tax Plan So Far
description: The vice president supports the tax increases proposed by the Biden White House, according to her campaign.
content: In a campaign otherwise light on policy specifics, Vice President Kamala Harris this week quietly rolled out her most detailed, far-ranging proposal yet: nearly $5 trillion in tax increases over a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Friday Briefing: A Brutal Reality for Women in India
description: Plus, saying goodbye to a penguin and an icon.
content: The Supreme Court of India this week took up the case of the ghastly rape and murder of a trainee doctor in a Kolkata hospital earlier this month. The case has convulsed the nation and led to doctor strikes and large street protests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Walker Mimms
title: Eco Art Is ‘In.’ Must It Always Speak Loudly?
description: As the climate alarm sounds, artists seem to want to instruct us. Two sculptors stray from the crowd with ambiguous, beautiful and frightening ecological works.
content: The environmental artist and activist Jenny Kendler favors a gentle form of persuasion when introducing ideas around climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: ‘Coach Walz’ Leads a Democratic Pep Rally
description: The vice-presidential nominee’s prime-time debut offered football analogies and an alternative to Trumpian masculinity.
content: The United Center arena in Chicago is the home of basketball’s Bulls and hockey’s Blackhawks. But you would be forgiven, Wednesday night at the Democratic National Convention, for thinking it was a football stadium — or rather, a locker room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitie Kelly
title: In Copenhagen, a Rooftop With a Farm and a Bar
description: Plus: a forest-inspired perfume, a Derrick Adams exhibition and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: April Gargiulo, the founder of the San Francisco-based beauty brand Vintner’s Daughter, first considered making a fragrance two years ago, when she connected with Loreto Remsing, a perfumer who’s also based in Northern California. Gargiulo and Remsing talked about how they might work together to bottle the landscape they both know well. Gargiulo’s creative prompt was “a magical liminal world between earth and sky, under the redwoods.” Remsing, Gargiulo says, “took this thing that was pretty esoteric and created something that was a perfect reflection of it.” Understory, a perfume oil with notes of violet, jasmine and moss, was released in 2022. This month, Vintner’s Daughter will debut Understory Vol. 2, which Gargiulo describes as a “new vintage” with subtle differences from its predecessor — the violet notes are stronger while the moss is softer in this iteration. title: Our Reporter on the Biggest Speech of Tim Walz’s Career
description: Gov. Tim Walz completed his transformation from a little-known governor to a leading party figure with his speech at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago on Wednesday night. As he gave the most consequential address of his career, attendees made clear that they had quickly become familiar with his life story, including his background as a former high school football coach. “We’re down a field goal,” he said. “But we’re on offense, and we’ve got the ball.”
